title: Hello World - Your First Program
description: Learn to write your first DWScript program and understand basic output

content.introduction:
Welcome to DWScript! In this lesson, you'll write your first program and learn about basic output.

Every programmer starts somewhere, and the traditional first program is "Hello World!" - a simple program that displays text on the screen.

### What You'll Learn
- How to structure a DWScript program
- Using `WriteLn` to output text
- Understanding the program structure

concepts.title: Program Structure
concepts.description: Every DWScript program has a clear structure with 'program' declaration, 'begin', and 'end' blocks

concepts.title: WriteLn Command
concepts.description: WriteLn outputs text to the console followed by a new line

concepts.title: String Literals
concepts.description: Text in DWScript is enclosed in single quotes ('text') or double quotes ("text")

examples.title: Basic Hello World
examples.description: The simplest DWScript program - outputs a greeting message

examples.title: Multiple Lines
examples.description: You can use multiple WriteLn statements to output several lines
examples.expectedOutput:
Welcome to DWScript!
This is line 2
This is line 3

examples.title: Using Write vs WriteLn
examples.description: Write outputs without a newline, WriteLn adds a newline after the text

exercises.title: Write Your Own Message
exercises.description: Create a program that outputs your name and a personal greeting message. Use at least 2 lines of output.
hints: You can use multiple WriteLn statements
Remember to use quotes around text
Don't forget the semicolon at the end of each statement

exercises.title: Creative Output
exercises.description: Create a program that outputs a simple text-based picture or pattern using multiple WriteLn statements. Be creative!
hints: Use spaces and special characters like *, #, +, etc.
Each WriteLn creates a new line
Try creating a simple shape like a star or tree

content.summary:
Congratulations! You've learned:

- How to structure a basic DWScript program
- Using `WriteLn` to display output
- The difference between `Write` and `WriteLn`
- How to create multi-line output

These are the fundamental building blocks you'll use in every program you write!
content.nextSteps: Next, you'll learn about **variables** and how to store and manipulate data in your programs. Variables are essential for creating dynamic, interactive programs.
